name: 2-aminopropane
source: Dreisbach R. R. Physical Properties of Chemical Compounds; Vol. III; American Chemical Society; Washington; 1961.
Reason: 2-Aminopropane has a melting point of -106.0 degrees Celsius. The basic unit for this compound can be considered propane (with a melting point of -18.0°C) because the amino group introduces a rigid structure and hydrogen bonding potential, which raises the melting point. The amino group also introduces additional molecular weight, which raises the melting point by approximately +10°C.
